EnablingAuthority.XRefExternal: COLLEGE OF PATENT AGENTS AND TRADEMARK AGENTS ACT

Identification.LongTitle: By-laws of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents (Board)

Provision.Text: The board of directors of The College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents, pursuant to section 75 of the College of Patent and Trademark Agents Acta, makes the annexed By-laws of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents (Board).

SignatureTitle.Language: Collège des agents de brevets et des agents de marques de commerce
College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these By-laws.

Definition.Text: Act means the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents Act. (Loi)
CEO means the Chief Executive Officer. (English version only)

class 1 with respect to a licence, describes either a patent agent licence issued under subsection 26(1) of the Act or a trademark agent licence issued under subsection 29(1) of the Act that is not covered by class 2. (catégorie 1)

class 2 with respect to a licence, describes either a patent agent licence issued under subsection 26(1) of the Act or a trademark agent licence issued under subsection 29(1) of the Act that is subject to the restrictions under section 27 of the By-laws of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents (College). (catégorie 2)

class 3 with respect to a licence, describes either a patent agent in training licence issued under subsection 26(2) of the Act or a trademark agent in training licence issued under subsection 29(2) of the Act. (catégorie 3)
non-resident patent agent means an individual who is described in subsection 19(1) of the Regulations. (agent de brevets non-résident)
non-resident trademark agent means an individual who is described in subsection 20(1) of the Regulations. (agent de marques de commerce non-résident)
Regulations means the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents Regulations. (Règlement)

Section.Text: The fiscal year of the College begins on January 1 and ends on December 31 of the same calendar year.
The electronic means by which licensees may attend the meeting under section 12 of the Act must be prescribed by the Board.
The CEO must give public notice at least 60 days before the day on which the annual general meeting takes place of the date, means of attendance and, if applicable, the location.
The agenda for an annual general meeting must contain the following items for discussion:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the CEO’s presentation of the College’s annual report and audited financial statements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Chairperson’s address to the meeting;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: questions from the licensees to the Board; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any additional matter the Board adds to the agenda.

Subsection.Text: Two of the directors elected to the Board must be patent agents and two must be trademark agents.

The term of office of each elected director begins at the conclusion of the first annual general meeting following their election and ends on the day that is three years after the day on which it begins or at the conclusion of the fourth annual general meeting following their election, whichever occurs first.

Despite subsection (2), the term of the patent agent and the trademark agent who each receive the second highest number of votes during the first election of directors ends on the day that is two years after the day on which it begins or at the conclusion of the third annual general meeting following their election, whichever occurs first.

Despite subsection (2), if a director is elected to replace a director whose position is vacated before their term is scheduled to end, the term of the replacement director ends when their predecessor’s term was scheduled to end.

Section.Text: A quorum of the Board is achieved if a majority of the directors are present at the meeting.

Subsection.Text: In the performance of its duties, the Board is to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on an annual basis, appoint an independent auditor to audit the accounts of the College and approve the audited financial statements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the College’s financial performance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designate any bank listed in Schedule I to the Bank Act as a bank for the College;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure multi-year financial planning by approving operating and capital budgets for the College in advance of each fiscal year;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish and publish an investment policy and appoint an investment dealer, on the recommendation of the CEO;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the College and the CEO’s actions are compliant with legal requirements; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with published policies, consult with working groups it establishes to assist with its duties and functions.

Subsection.Text: The Board’s duties with respect to the CEO are to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide directions to the work of the CEO with established performance expectations, succession planning and regular performance reviews;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: develop regulatory objectives, standards and principles;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establish any working groups to assist in carrying out the CEO’s work;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the performance of the CEO and of the working groups; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: oversee effective relations and engagement with members and the public.

Section.Text: The Board may, on the credit of the College,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: borrow money and, to that end, charge, mortgage, hypothecate, cede and transfer, pledge or otherwise create an interest in or charge on any property held by the College; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pledge any securities or cash that it holds, or give deposits, as security for the payment or performance of any obligation of the College.

Subsection.Text: Except in the case of gross or intentional fault, the College must indemnify and save harmless out of the funds of the College every director, committee member and employee or appointee, namely the investigators, and their personal representative, succession or estate, against all of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the costs inherent to any action against them in the execution of their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any reasonable costs, charges, expenses, awards and damages they sustain or incur in or about or in relation to the affairs of the College.

Subsection.Text: The CEO may indemnify a service provider of the College if the CEO advises the Board in writing in advance.

Section.Text: The officers of the College are the Chairperson, Vice-chairperson and the CEO, who serves ex officio and does not have a vote at any meeting of the Board.
The duties of the Chairperson are to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carry out the College’s business;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: act as a spokesperson for the Board; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: participate in the Board’s decision making.

Section.Text: The duties of the Vice-chairperson are to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: perform the duties of the Chairperson if the Chairperson cannot perform those duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carry out the duties and responsibilities assigned to the office; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: participate in the Board’s decision making.

Section.Text: If the office of Chairperson becomes vacant, the Vice-chairperson becomes the Chairperson until the election of a new Chairperson.
If the office of Vice-chairperson becomes vacant, the Board must choose a director to serve as Vice-chairperson to hold office until the election of a new Vice-chairperson.
The Board may remove the Chairperson from office if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it gives at least two weeks notice in writing before the day of the vote in respect of the removal; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Vice-chairperson presides over the meeting during which the vote is held; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the directors, by a vote of two-thirds, support the removal.

Section.Text: The Board is to meet at least four times per year. The Board sets the location of the meeting or the electronic means to be used in order to hold the meeting.
A meeting held by electronic means must be conducted by any means that permits all persons participating in the meeting to communicate with each other simultaneously.
Board meetings, except a meeting of the committee-of-the-whole are open to the public.

Subsection.Text: At least seven days before a Board meeting, the CEO must publish on the College’s website

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the agenda and meeting materials that are not confidential; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any information that enables the public to participate in the meeting, including how the public can access the meeting if it is to be held by electronic means.

Subsection.Text: Failure of the CEO to publish the notice does not invalidate the meeting.

Section.Text: A board meeting agenda must relate only to the Board’s work.
A motion that is tabled at a Board meeting is decided by a majority vote of the directors present at the meeting.
A resolution adopted at a Board meeting by a majority of directors is valid.
The Board must adopt rules of order.

The Chairperson may, with the consent of a majority of directors present, adjourn a meeting to a fixed time and place, and any matter that was on the agenda at the original meeting may be considered and transacted at a reconvened meeting .
The Board may exclude the CEO from an in camera meeting in order to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consider the CEO’s appointment, reappointment, dismissal, performance or terms of office; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide an opportunity for the directors to discuss matters relevant only to them.

Subsection.Text: The Chairperson, or any three directors, may call a special Board meeting to be held by electronic means, by providing at least 24 hours written notice to the CEO.
The CEO, on receipt of the notice, must, as soon as possible

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: advise the directors and the public of the reason, the date and time, and the electronic means for participating in the meeting;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publish on the College’s website the agenda and meeting materials that are not confidential.

Subsection.Text: Failure of the CEO to publish the notice does not invalidate the meeting.

Section.Text: The College pays a per diem of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $750 for the Chairperson; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: $550 for Board and committee members.

Section.Text: Directors and committee members are reimbursed for the reasonable expenses they have incurred for transaction of the College’s business.
The CEO must, at the time the College submits its annual report to the Minister, make public the amounts paid as remuneration and expenses to directors and committee members.

Subsection.Text: Each year, the Governance and Nominating Committee determines if any elected director positions will be vacant at the conclusion of the next annual general meeting, in which case an election must be held before that meeting to elect the appropriate number of patent agents and trademark agents to satisfy the requirements of subsection 6(1).
The CEO must publish the dates on the College’s website for all aspects of the election process.
The CEO is responsible for the administration of the election process.
The Board may appoint an election commissioner to address any issues arising in the election process.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subparagraphs 14(f)(ii) and 17(h)(iii) of the Act, the ineligibility criteria are the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the five years immediately preceding the election day, the individual

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has been found to have committed professional misconduct or been found to be incompetent by the Discipline Committee, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has been found to have committed professional misconduct or been found to be incompetent by a tribunal of a body that has a statutory duty to regulate a profession;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the individual is the subject of an application by the Investigations Committee to the Discipline Committee under subsection 49(1) of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the individual has served as a director for the six years immediately preceding the election day;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the individual has not provided a declaration regarding conflicts of interest; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the individual has not attended an orientation for prospective candidates, facilitated by the Governance and Nominating Committee.

Subsection.Text: The CEO must refer a dispute about the ineligibility of a nominee for a position as a board member to the Election Commissioner who, following receipt of the reasons for the CEO’s determination regarding ineligibility and a submission from the prospective nominee, must rule on ineligibility.
The ruling of the Election Commissioner is not subject to review by the Board.

Section.Text: Elections for directors are to be held electronically.
The Board must establish and publish on the College’s website an election policy.

Subsection.Text: Any dispute that arises during the election period or regarding the election results are to be ruled on by the Election Commissioner.
The ruling of the Election Commissioner is not subject to review by the Board.

Section.Text: A licensee whose licence is not suspended is eligible to vote in an election for directors.
A candidate who withdraws from an election must give notice in writing to the CEO.

Subsection.Text: If a candidate asserts that there are reasonable grounds to dispute the validity of the election process, the candidate may file a notice of dispute with the Governance and Nominating Committee.
If the Committee finds that the notice gives reasonable grounds to doubt the validity of the election process, they must hold an inquiry into the validity of the election process.
Following its inquiry, the Governance and Nominating Committee must make a report and recommendations to the Board.
After reviewing the report and recommendation of the Governance and Nominating Committee, the Board may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: declare the election result to be valid; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: declare the election result to be invalid and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: may disqualify an apparently successful candidate and declare another candidate to have been elected, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: direct that another election be held.

Subsection.Text: The Board is not to declare an election result invalid based on a minor irregularity with respect to the election process.

Section.Text: If there is a vacancy on the Board for an elected director, the Board may appoint a person with the requisite qualifications to fill the vacancy for the remainder of the term.
The directors, by a vote of two-thirds, may remove an elected director from office for cause if notice of the intention to make the motion is provided to the Board at least two weeks in advance.

The directors, by a vote of two-thirds, may ask that a request to the Minister be made to remove an appointed director from office for cause if notice of the intention to make the motion is provided to the Board at least two weeks in advance.
A director who, without a valid reason, is absent from two consecutive meetings of the Board has met the ineligibility criteria under subparagraph 17(h)(iii) of the Act.
The committees that assist the Board in the exercise of their functions are the

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: committee of the College referred to in section 3 of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Governance and Nominating Committee; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Audit and Risk Committee.

Section.Text: The duties of the CEO are to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain accurate minutes of Board meetings and have them approved by the Board and maintained by the College;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide leadership, support and strategic advice to the Board to assist it in meeting its obligations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: manage, coordinate and maintain the College’s operations, administration, finances and organization;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: develop operation and management policies;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: counsel and assist the Board and committees in carrying out their assigned functions;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: engage, direct and supervise employees and contractors of the College and develop succession plans for College staff and contracted functions;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: assist the Board in complying with the Act, regulations, by-laws and policies affecting it;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: act as the spokesperson for the College; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: perform all other functions and duties as assigned by the Board.

Subsection.Text: The Board may appoint a Deputy CEO who serves as acting CEO in the CEO’s absence.
If the office of CEO becomes vacant and there is no Deputy CEO, the Board must appoint an acting CEO until a new CEO is appointed.
The Board may appoint a Deputy Registrar who serves as acting Registrar during the Registrar’s absence.
If a vacancy occurs in the office of Registrar and there is no Deputy Registrar, the Board must, as soon as feasible, appoint an acting Registrar until a new Registrar is appointed.
The Registrar establishes regulatory policies on their own initiative or at the request of the Board or one of the committees.
The Registrar must publish the regulatory policies on the College’s website.

Section.Text: The Registrar may remove any of a licensee’s personal information from the Registers under sections 28 or 31 of the Act.
A licensee must advise the Registrar in writing if the licensee

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is served with an application for a bankruptcy, makes an assignment of property for the benefit of creditors or presents a proposal in bankruptcy to creditors under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has had a judgment entered against them by a court;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is personally subject to an order for costs;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is charged with, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of any offence under the Criminal Code, the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, the Income Tax Act, the Excise Tax Act or under a provincial securities act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has been found to have committed professional misconduct or been found to be incompetent by a tribunal of a body that has a statutory duty to regulate a profession.

Section.Text: On or before March 31 of each year, a licensee who holds a class 1 licence must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pay to the College the applicable fee set out in item 1 or 2 of the schedule;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: file with the Registrar the Annual Licensee Report; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Registrar with proof of professional liability insurance or proof of exemption from that insurance.

Section.Text: The Annual Licensee Report must contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the licensee’s mailing address, civic address, email address, telephone number, firm name and address, language proficiency for the delivery of patent or trademark services, areas of practice and the approximate percentage by time or billings associated with each area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licensee’s continuing professional development plans; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the licensee’s insurer and the policy number of the licensee’s professional liability insurance or the reason for the licensee’s exemption.

Section.Text: A licensee who holds a class 2 licence must pay to the College the fee set out in item 5 of the schedule on or before March 31 of each year.
On or before the anniversary each year of the effective date of their licence, a licensee who holds a class 3 licence must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pay to the College the fee set out in item 7 of the schedule and, in the case of the second or subsequent anniversary, the fee set out in item 8 of the schedule; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Registrar with either the name of the insurer that has insured them against professional liability and their insurance policy number or proof that they are exempt from the requirement to be so insured and the reason for the exemption.

Subsection.Text: The following licensees are exempt from the requirement under subsection 34(1) of the Act to be insured against professional liability:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: class 2 licensees; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: licensees who are employed by a corporation, including a municipal corporation, or a trust, partnership, sole proprietorship, joint venture, association, agency or other entity that carries on business in Canada, whether or not for profit, and are working as licensees within the scope of that employment.

Subsection.Text: The professional liability insurance that must be maintained by a licensee under subsection 34(1) of the Act must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be issued by a company licensed in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cover claims made in and outside Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: indemnify the licensee for any civil liability that arises from the licensee acting as a patent agent or trademark agent, as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have coverage limits of no less than $1 million per claim and $2 million aggregate per year.

Section.Text: The Registrar may, having regard to the specific circumstances of the licensee, extend the deadline for payment of fees by any class of license or filing of the Annual Licensee Report by class 1 licensees.

Subsection.Text: Notification under subsection 35(2) of the Act must be given to the licensee at least seven days in advance of the suspension of the licence takes effect and must contain the reasons for the suspension.

The Registrar must reinstate a person whose licence has been suspended if the person corrects the matter that resulted in the suspension and pays to the College the fee set out in item 16 of the schedule within two years after the day on which the licence was suspended.
A person whose licence has been suspended for more than two years may apply to have their licence reinstated if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: correct the matter that resulted in the suspension;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pay to the College the fee set out in item 16 of the schedule; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: complete the required continuing professional development requirements.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsection 35(4) of the Act, the Registrar must revoke a licence that has been suspended for at least five consecutive years by providing notice to the licensee’s last known email address 30 days before the day on which the revocation takes effect.

Subsection.Text: An application to surrender a licence under section 36 of the Act is to be made by providing the following information to the Registrar and by paying to the College the fee set out in item 15 of the schedule and any other outstanding fees owed by the licensee:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current and, if applicable, future contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the licensee’s professional employment history;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: confirmation in writing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that all client matters have been completed or that arrangements have been made to the satisfaction of the licensee’s clients to have the client’s files returned to the client or transferred to another licensee,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that any matters in progress at the Canadian Intellectual Property Office have been assigned to another licensee and the office has been advised in writing of the successor licensee, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: of the location of the files from the licensee’s practice.

Subsection.Text: If the Registrar is satisfied that the information they received is sufficient and has confirmed that the applicant is not the subject of a complaint or an investigation under section 37 of the Act, or an application under paragraph 32(b), the Registrar must accept the surrender and set the effective date of surrender.
The Registrar may, upon request

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give information to assist in determining if the request merits an investigation into professional misconduct or incompetence of the licensee; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take all reasonable steps toward resolving the request.

Subsection.Text: The request must be submitted on a form provided by the Registrar and must contain all the information with respect to the relationship between the person making the request and the licensee as well as the nature of their concerns.
The Registrar may refuse the request and return the matter to the person making the request, with reasons, if the request

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: falls outside the College’s jurisdiction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is premature;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on its face does not amount to a failure of a licensee to meet the standards of professional conduct and competence established by the code of professional conduct made under subsection 33(1) of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is made for an improper purpose, including

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to seek relief that is the jurisdiction of civil courts,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: to harass a licensee’s client if the person making the request has an adverse interest,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: to gather information to be used in another proceeding; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: lacks substance or a factual basis.

Section.Text: The Registrar may, on the request of a licensee and on payment to the College of the fee set out in item 17 of the schedule, produce a certificate that sets out information within the Registrar’s knowledge.

Heading.TitleText: Non-resident Patent Agents and Non-resident Trademark Agents

Section.Text: The request referred to in paragraph 19(1)(b) or 20(1)(b) of the Regulations must be accompanied by the fee set out in item 18 of the schedule, payable to the College.

Subsection.Text: A non-resident patent agent and a non-resident trademark agent must provide the statement referred to in subsection 19(2) or 20(2), respectively, of the Regulations each year during the period beginning on May 1 and ending on June 30.
The statement must be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: proof, furnished by the relevant competent authority in the person’s country of residence, that the person is authorized to act as a patent agent or trademark agent, as the case may be, in that country; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the fee set out in item 19 of the schedule, payable to the College.

Subsection.Text: The Registrar may, having regard to the specific circumstances of a non-resident patent agent or non-resident trademark agent, extend the deadline for payment of the fee referred to in paragraph (2)(b).

Section.Text: A non-resident patent agent and a non-resident trademark agent must inform the Registrar, in writing and without delay, if they cease to be a resident of a country other than Canada or cease to be authorized to act as such an agent in that country.

Subsection.Text: The Registrar must remove from the Register of Patent Agents or the Register of Trademark Agents, as the case may be, the name and contact information of any person who is included in that Register as a non-resident patent agent or a non-resident trademark agent if they are no longer an individual referred to in paragraph 19(1)(a) or 20(1)(a), respectively, of the Regulations.

The Registrar may remove from the Register of Patent Agents or the Register of Trademark Agents the name and contact information of a non-resident patent agent or non-resident trademark agent who does not meet the requirements of section 60.3 or subsection 19(2) or 20(2), respectively, of the Regulations.

Section.Text: A licensee who is making all reasonable efforts to become insured against professional liability as soon as feasible is, until December 31, 2022, exempt from the requirement under subsection 34(1) of the Act to be so insured.

Section.MarginalNote: Revocation patent agent licence — country other than Canada

Subsection.Text: On the day of coming into force of these By-laws, the Registrar must revoke the patent agent licence of any individual whose name is included in the Register of Patent Agents under section 19 of the College of Patent Agents and Trademarks Agent Regulations.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Revocation trademark agent licence — country other than Canada
Subsection.Text: On the day of coming into force of these By-laws, the Registrar must revoke the trademark agent licence of any individual whose name is included in the Register of Trademark Agents under section 20 of the College of Patent Agents and Trademarks Agent Regulations

Section.Text: These By-laws come into force on the day on which paragraph 76(1)(c) of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents Act, section 247 of chapter 27 of the Statutes of Canada, 2018, comes into force, but if they are registered after that day, they come into force on the day on which they are registered.

Footnote.Text: [Note: By-laws in force June 28, 2021, see SI/2021-30.]

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE
ScheduleFormHeading.OriginatingRef: (Paragraph 52(a), section 54, paragraph 55(a), subsection 57(2), paragraph 57(3)(b), subsection 59(1), sections 60.1 and 60.2 and paragraph 60.3(2)(b))

row.entry: Annual Class 1 License (both patent agent and trademark agent)
Annual fee to extend Class 3 registration [beyond 24 months]
Non-resident agent initial inclusion in Register
Non-resident agent annual maintenance of name in Register

Section.Text: The following By-laws are repealed:

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: By-laws of the College of Patent Agents and Trademark Agents (Board)2.
